description: From Middle English kag, from Old Norse kaggi (“keg”), likely a diminutive of Proto-Germanic *kagô (“bush, branch, stalk, stump”). Cognate with Icelandic kaggi (“keg; cask”), Norwegian kagg (“keg”), Swedish kagge (“keg”), Low German kag (“vessel; craft”), Dutch kaag (“vessel; craft”). Compare also English cag and chag.

The modern form keg with /ɛ/ is due to a dialectal raising of /a///æ/ to /ɛ/ before velars (cf. fleg); the expected form is preserved in dialectal /kæɡ/, while /keɪɡ/ reflects further raising that occurred in some dialects.

entries.meaning: A round, traditionally wooden container of lesser capacity than a barrel, often used to store beer.

verbs.description: keg (third-person singular simple present kegs, present participle kegging, simple past and past participle kegged)

examples: He gestured toward the empty chair and the other officers began passing him their kegged beef and ship's biscuit.
